si9.svg svg 2500 ALTIMG JECHEM 4579 S2095-4956(25)00256-6 10.1016/j.jechem.2025.03.041 Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 (a) Schematic illustrations of material preparation; (b) XRD patterns of different materials; SEM images of (c) 3 N-FeNi@CNTs and (d) 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs; (e) TEM ((e-1) inset: macrostructure of yardlong bean), (f) HRTEM (inset: IFFT patterns), (g) SAED pattern (inset: crystal structures of Fe9Ni9S16 and FeS), and (h) STEM and corresponding elemental mapping images of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs. Fig. 2 High-resolution XPS spectra of (a) Fe 2p and (b) Ni 2p in xN-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs; Density of states of (c) FeS and (d) Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterojunction (inset: corresponding local magnified image and crystal structure); (e) Schematic illustration of the induced built-in electric field at the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterointerface for rapid ion (M+) diffusion. Fig. 3 Electrochemical performance for Na-ion storage: (a) CV curves of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs in ether-based electrolyte at 0.1 mV s−1; (b) Cycling performance of different electrodes at 0.1 A g−1; (c) GCD curves and (d) dQ/dV plots (sodiation process) of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs at 0.1 A g−1 for different cycles; (e) Rate capability of diverse electrodes and (f) GCD curves of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs at various rates; (g) Rate capability and (h) cycling performance comparison of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs with other recently developed metal sulfide electrodes; (i) Long-term cycling performance of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs in ether/ester-based electrolytes at 1 A g−1. Fig. 4 Reaction mechanism investigation: Surface and cross-section SEM images of (a) pristine 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs electrode and (b) same electrode after 100 cycles in the ether-based electrolyte; (c) Raman spectra, (d) XRD patterns, and high-resolution (e) Fe 2p and (f) Ni 2p XPS spectra of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs under different states in the ether-based electrolyte; Ex-situ HRTEM images (inset: IFFT patterns) and SAED patterns of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs in (g) full sodiation and (h) full desodiation; (i) Schematic illustration of structure evolution of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs during sodiation/desodiation processes. Fig. 5 Kinetic and thermodynamic analysis of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs for Na-ion storage: (a, c) Isothermal heating map and (b, d) capacitive contribution ratio in ether-based and ester-based electrolytes at diverse scan rates; GITT profile and corresponding Na+ diffusion coefficient in (e) (inset: volume evolution diagram during the cycle) ether-based and (f) ester-based electrolytes; (g, i) Nyquist plots (inset: corresponding equivalent circuit model), (h, j) and corresponding linear relations of Zre versus ω-0.5 under various electrolytes and cycles; (k) Na+ adsorption energies at different adsorption sites on Fe and Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterojunctions (inset: top and side view). Graphic abstract A novel type of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure with sulfur vacancies in situ encapsulated within N-doped carbon nanotubes was initially prepared through a successive pyrolysis and sulfidation strategy. The heterostructure material, with a built-in electric field, not only enables fast ion diffusion and electron transfer, along with favorable capacitive behavior, but also enhances robust storage performance and cycle stability. Tailoring 1D nanotubes with refined interfacial interactions and optimized adsorption sites presents a highly promising yet challenging strategy for advancing Na/Li-ion batteries (SIBs/LIBs). Herein, the intertwined yardlong bean-like Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructures with sulfur vacancies encapsulated in N-doped carbon nanotubes (3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs) are controllably synthesized through Fe/Ni-catalyzed pyrolysis of dicyandiamide followed by sulfidation strategies. 1D nanotubes with robust outer walls and internal cavity structures shorten the diffusion paths of ions/electrons and buffer volume expansion and aggregation of active materials. The Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure provides a powerful driving force for charge transfer by forming built-in electric fields, optimizing ion adsorption, while the Fe9Ni9S16 features a wider interlayer spacing that allows for frequent Na+/Li+ insertion and extraction, thereby enhancing the reaction kinetics within the electrode. Driven by these synergistic factors, the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs demonstrates remarkable electrochemical performance, achieving a substantial reversible capacity of up to 682.1mA h g−1 for SIBs at 0.1 A g−1 and 782.7 mA h g−1 for LIBs at 0.5 A g−1, alongside exceptional cycling stability in SIBs, maintaining 78.7% of its capacity after 1500 cycles at 1 A g−1 coupling with the ether-based electrolyte. Employing various electrochemical analyses in conjunction with ex-situ characterization techniques and Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations, the storage mechanisms and phase transition processes are investigated, elucidating the structure-composition-performance relationships. This work paves the way for a new strategy in designing advanced materials with engineered heterostructures and controllable defects for energy conversion and storage devices. Keywords Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure Interfacial electron regulation N-doped carbon nanotube DFT calculation Na/Li-ion storage 1 Introduction The rational design of micro/nanostructured electrode materials is crucial for tailoring the structure–composition–performance relationships in sodium/lithium-ion batteries (SIBs/LIBs) [1]. Particularly, architectures integrating both external walls and internal cavities/lumens offer significant advantages by facilitating ion transport and mitigating volume expansion—critical factors given the larger ionic radius of Na+ [2,3]. Despite these structural advancements, challenges persist, including the inherently lower theoretical capacity of sodium and the limited availability of lithium [1,4]. Thus, developing cost-effective anode materials with high capacity, excellent rate performance, and long-term cycling stability remains an urgent priority. Among the various candidates, transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) have attracted extensive interest due to their 2D plane structures, which resemble graphite, featuring covalently bonded in-plane atoms and weak van der Waals interlayer interactions that promote fast redox kinetics and efficient electrochemical conversion reactions [5,6]. Notably, iron and nickel sulfides (Fe1- x S and Ni1- x S; 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.5) exhibit competitive theoretical capacities and excellent electrochemical reversibility in SIBs and LIBs [4,6]. Unfortunately, similar to other metal sulfides, the unsatisfactory rate capability and rapid capacity fading caused by poor electronic conductivity, severe nanoparticle aggregation, and huge volume fluctuations substantially limit their widespread application in SIBs and LIBs [7]. To address these limitations, multiple strategies—heterostructure engineering, defect modulation, vacancy regulation, and dimensional reduction—have been explored to enhance the electrochemical properties of electrode materials [8–10]. This approach enhances ion/electron transport efficiency, accelerates redox reactions, and bolsters structural integrity, ultimately improving overall electrochemical performance [6,11,12]. For instance, Ren et al. developed a NiS2/FeS2 heterostructure encapsulated in multichannel N-doped carbon nanofibers (NiS2/FeS2@MCNFs) using coprecipitation, electrospinning, and carbonization/sulfurization techniques, achieving a high reversible capacity of 350 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1 [7]. However, the nonpolar nature of carbon nanomaterials hinders the formation of strong interface electronic coupling with polar Fe1- x S (Ni1- x S), typically leading to higher interface electron transfer resistance and insufficient constraint on Fe1- x S (Ni1- x S) during cycling, ultimately contributing to long-term performance degradation [13]. To overcome these limitations, Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructures are introduced, where Fe9Ni9S16 provides abundant active sites for Na+/Li+ storage, while FeS facilitates rapid charge transport due to its relatively high electrical conductivity. The synergistic interaction at the heterointerface enhances charge redistribution, reduces ion diffusion barriers, and improves structural stability, making it an ideal candidate for high-performance Na+/Li+ storage. Doped 1D carbon nanotubes (CNTs) exhibit significant energy storage potential by buffering volume expansion and reducing the degradation risk of active nanoparticles, while vacancy defects introduced via doping enhance electrochemical performance by modulating electronic and crystallographic properties [9,11,14,15]. Unlike commercial CNTs, which often exhibit uncontrollable aggregation, the in-situ growth of heteroatom-doped CNTs on tailored substrates preserves their structural advantages, enabling superior energy storage performance [16]. Cyanamide-based precursors, such as melamine and dicyandiamide, contain highly reactive cyano (−CN) and amino (–NH2) groups, making them ideal for nitrogen-doped carbon synthesis. When pyrolyzed in the presence of transition metals (Fe, Co, Ni, etc.) at high temperatures, these precursors yield materials with high electrical conductivity, abundant nitrogen doping, hierarchical porosity, and excellent chemical stability, which have been widely applied in supercapacitors [17], electrocatalysis [18], and microwave attenuation [19]. Inspired by these advances, we employ in-situ pyrolysis of dicyandiamide to integrate N-doped CNTs, enabling the fabrication of high-performance composite anodes for SIBs and LIBs. Beyond material design, electrolyte selection plays a crucial role in dictating the structural evolution and electrochemical behavior of electrodes throughout cycling. Yang et al. showcased that the MNS-HNT@NC electrode exhibits excellent capacity retention and electrochemical stability when paired with an ether-based electrolyte as an anode for SIBs [9]. Hence, the synergistic combination of rational heterostructure engineering, N-doped CNT confinement, and appropriate electrolyte selection is expected to simultaneously optimize the electrochemical behavior of electrodes, making them viable for both SIBs and LIBs. Herein, iron/nickel sulfide-based heterostructures featuring sulfur vacancies encapsulated in space-confined N-doped CNTs (3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs) were controllably tailored for the first time through in-situ carbonization and sulfidation strategies. High-temperature annealing under a reducing atmosphere induces sulfur evaporation and dissociation, leading to the formation of sulfur vacancies during the FeS-to-Fe9Ni9S16 transformation. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the hybridization of Fe9Ni9S16 and FeS at different Fermi levels induces charge redistribution at heterointerfaces with sulfur vacancies, leading to alterations in interfacial properties and modifications in the local electronic structure of the active materials. This phenomenon creates new redox-active sites, enhances Na+/Li+ adsorption, and improves both interfacial and internal charge transfer between Fe9Ni9S16 and FeS, thereby significantly enhancing the conductivity of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs. The intertwined yardlong bean-like structure of NCNTs, with robust outer walls and internal cavities, shortens ion/electron diffusion paths, buffers volume changes, minimizes direct contact between active materials and electrolytes, and facilitates the formation of a stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) membrane, ultimately enhancing battery stability. As a result of the synergistic effects, the composite exhibits outstanding electrochemical performance, including a high reversible capacity of 682.1 mA h g−1 or SIBs at 0.1 A g−1 and 782.7 mA h g−1 for LIBs at 0.5 A g−1, along with good cycling stability in SIBs, retaining 78.7% of its capacity after 1500 cycles at 1 A g−1 in an ether-based electrolyte. Through comprehensive electrochemical kinetic analysis and ex-situ characterization, the storage mechanisms are elucidated, emphasizing the significant role of heterostructures in accelerating ion/electron diffusion. The results reveal a high capacitive contribution of 81.6% for SIBs and 86.0% for LIBs at 1 mV s−1, showcasing the effectiveness of our tailored heterostructure design in optimizing electrochemical kinetics. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Material formation mechanism The preparation process of xN-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-y@CNTs is schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 a. Herein, the coordination between Fe3+/Ni2+ and cyanogen groups (–CN) in dicyandiamide (DCD) was leveraged to yield monodispersed xFe/Ni-DCD precursors as template. To elucidate the coordination relationship between Fe3+/Ni2+ and DCD, the Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectrum of 3Fe/Ni-DCD is presented in Fig. S1. The peaks noted at 3430–3150, 2210/2160, 1640, 1260, and 930 cm−1 are assigned to the stretching vibrations of –NH2/–NH–, –CN, –C=N–, –C–N–, and –C–N–C–, respectively. The bands at approximately 558 cm−1 is indicative of the Fe/Ni–N vibrations arising from the coordination of N with Fe/Ni in 3Fe/Ni-DCD [20]. Of particular note, during the subsequent carbonization process, the significant release of C/N substances from DCD decomposition causes surface rupture of the Fe/Ni catalyst, facilitating the in-situ encapsulation of FeNi NPs into NCNTs through carbon thermal reduction [21]. In turn, the high catalytic activity of iron/nickel components promotes NCNTs formation, culminating in the synthesis of the xN-FeNi@CNTs composite material [22]. Through in situ catalysis growth facilitated by FeNi NPs within the 1D nanotubes, the NCNTs developed well-defined, closely integrated interfaces with the FeNi NPs [19]. This growth mechanism is analogous to the germination process of yardlong bean: the abundant Fe/Ni NPs in xFe/Ni-DCD precursors represent the raw “beans”, while the catalytic action of metal Fe/Ni transforms DCD vapor into the “stem” of the NCNTs, as explained by the “vapor–liquid-solid” (VLS) model [14,23]. The ensuing in-situ sulfidation process transforms the xN-FeNi@CNTs into Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructures encapsulated by NCNTs. During the synthesis of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructures, the high reactivity of Fe leads to the formation of FeS through its reaction with S, which in turn promotes the displacement of S atoms from NiS, creating sulfur vacancies, and subsequently induces the formation of Fe9Ni9S16 under high-temperature conditions, with the high reactivity of Fe allowing it to dominate in its reaction with S. 2.2 Material characterization analysis To preliminarily ascertain the phase structure transition of as-prepared materials, X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analyses were first conducted. As illustrated in Fig. 1b and Fig. S3a, the diffraction peaks in the as-prepared xN-FeNi@CNTs can be accurately matched with the cubic Fe, Ni or Fe-Ni alloy (JCPDS No. 6–696, 87–712 or 47–1405), indicating the effective transformation from xFe/Ni-DCD to N-doped CNTs-encapsulated x-FeNi. In comparison to N-Fe@CNTs and N-Ni@CNTs, the diffraction peaks of Ni and Fe metals in xN-FeNi@CNTs shift towards lower angles, suggesting an expansion in the crystal plane spacing under the mutual influence of Fe and Ni, leading to the successful formation of the FeNi alloy (Fig. S3a) [24]. Afterwards, a comprehensive investigation was conducted on metal sulfide composites synthesized with varying sulfur and hybrid metal ratios (Fig. 1b and Fig. S4a-c). Evidently, with the increasing sulfur ratio, the precursor xN-FeNi@CNTs gradually undergoes sulfurization, initially forming FeS and subsequently evolving into Fe9Ni9S16 until complete sulfurization occurs, suggesting metallic Fe is more prone to oxidation than Ni. As the nickel ratio rises, the diffraction peak intensity of Fe9Ni9S16 progressively dominates, leading to the near-complete disappearance of FeS peak intensity. The transformation of the final product from 3 N-FeNi@CNTs to 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs is verified by XRD phase analysis, aligning with the characteristic patterns in JCPDS cards (No. 75–2024, 75–602, and 26–1077), confirming the successful construction of the desired heterostructure. Notably, as illustrated in the XRD pattern (Fig. 1b), the Fe9Ni9S16 crystalline phase exhibits more pronounced low-angle diffraction peaks, indicating a larger interlayer spacing compared to FeS, which enhances the potential of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructures for facilitating rapid Na-ion reaction kinetics. In comparing, the XRD patterns of single-phase N-FeS-3@CNTs and N-Ni3S2-3@CNTs can be associated with cubic FeS and rhombohedral Ni3S2, respectively. The morphological features of the as-prepared composites were investigated utilizing scanning and transmission electron microscopy (SEM/TEM). The SEM images of 3 N-FeNi@CNTs at different magnifications in Fig. 1c show intertwined yardlong bean-like nanotubes with smooth surfaces, indicating the transformation from 3Fe/Ni-DCD to Fe/Ni nanoparticles confined within N-doped carbon nanotubes after carbonization. Moreover, Fig. 1c-2 ,3 present the SEM images with higher magnification, showcasing a combination of open and closed tips, with distinctively bright dots observed within certain tips. The closed tips are identified as nanoparticles, which have been previously validated as nucleation sites for N-doped carbon nanotube growth in earlier research [25]. The N atoms from ammonia produced by the decomposition of DCD at high temperatures disrupt the hexagonal honeycomb arrangement of carbon nanotubes, promoting the formation of pentagonal rings that lower the system’s energy and establish a stable structural configuration [16,26]. The introduction of pentagonal ring-bent lattices and curved segments results in a fullerene-like structure, generating abundant curved and enclosed yardlong bean-like configurations within the carbon nanotubes [27,28]. The Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) images (Fig. S2) indicate the homogeneous distribution of C, N, Fe, Ni and O in the 3 N-FeNi@CNTs, with corresponding elemental compositions. For comparison, SEM images in Fig. S3b-e depict varying magnifications of N-Fe@CNTs, N-Ni@CNTs, 1.5 N-FeNi@CNTs, and 1 N-FeNi@CNTs. Remarkably, all samples exhibit intertwined yardlong bean-like nanotubes, with some subtle differences: i) the surface of N-Ni@CNTs appears rougher than that of N-Fe@CNTs, possibly due to lower compatibility of Ni with carbon, which may constrain the diffusion of carbon atoms; ii) as the Ni ratio increases in N-Fe@CNTs, the diameter and quality of carbon nanotubes gradually decrease, accompanied by more irregular and dense carbon aggregates, likely due to the excessive inhibitory effect of Ni catalysts on carbon nanotube formation. Furthermore, SEM images of xN-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-y@CNTs, N-FeS-3@CNTs, and N-Ni3S2-3@CNTs in Fig. 1d and S4d-i demonstrate similar morphologies with well-maintained nanotube structures from the precursors, suggesting minimal impact from the sulfidation treatment. TEM image of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs (Fig. 1e-1) reveals the intertwined NCNTs with diameters ranging from 10 to over 100 nm. Within these NCNTs, metal particles are observed enclosed at multiple sites, aligning with the morphology-inheritance pathway of precursor materials during chemical phase conversion. The NCNTs corrugated outer wall encloses a lumen divided by numerous knots, while a closer view in Fig. 1e-2,3 reveal that NCNTs individual segments are interconnected, forming a yardlong bean-like morphology (inset of Fig. 1e-1). Incorporating hollow NCNTs with embedded Fe9Ni9S16/FeS nanoparticles represents a viable approach to mitigate the volume expansion experienced by the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS/NCNT heterostructure during electrochemical cycling, facilitating the preservation of the electrode’s structural integrity throughout the electrochemical processes [25]. The HRTEM image (Fig. 1f) reveals that the around 65 nm Fe9Ni9S16/FeS nanoparticle is fully encapsulated within the NCNT structure, which consists of 12–20 graphene layers. The lattice spacing of these graphene layers, ranging from 0.38 to 0.41 nm, suggests N doping in the carbon plane, slightly increasing the spacing compared to conventional CNTs. Supplemented by the crystal plane lattice spacing periodogram (Fig. S6), the identification of lattice fringes exhibiting d-spacings of 0.306 nm corresponding to the (311) plane of Fe9Ni9S16 and 0.262 nm corresponding to the (101) planes of FeS provides crucial structural insights, revealing the high crystallinity of the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS nanoparticles. The distinct heterointerface delineating between Fe9Ni9S16 and FeS is readily discernible, providing additional evidence for the successful preparation of the heterostructures. As depicted in inset of Fig. 1f, the lattice distortion observed in the IFFT mode serves as direct evidence confirming the existence of defects within the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs structure, where these defect sites not only significantly enhance ion transport kinetics by facilitating more effective ion adsorption but also act as crucial “bridges” that promote seamless charge transfer between the Fe9Ni9S16 and FeS phases, thus contributing to the overall improvement of the electrochemical performance. Additionally, the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs (Fig. 1g) reveals well-defined diffraction rings that can be accurately assigned to the (311), (400), (440), and (800) planes of cubic Fe9Ni9S16, as well as the (101) and (102) planes of hexagonal FeS. The scanning TEM (STEM) and EDS elemental mappings (Fig. 1h), coupled with SEM-EDS (Fig. S5), depict uniform distribution of C and N elements within the tube walls, whereas Fe, Ni, and S are concentrated within the lumens of the nanotubes, further illustrating an intertwined yardlong bean-like structure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to elucidate the surface chemical composition and bonding configuration of 3 N-FeNi@CNTs and xN-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs. As depicted in Fig. S7a, b and Table. S1, the full-survey XPS spectra of xN-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs distinctly reveal the presence of elements C, N, Fe, Ni, O, and S, providing evidence that the xN-FeNi@CNTs were effectively sulfided. The N 1 s spectrum (Fig. S7c) displays five peaks at binding energies of 407.58, 403.32, 400.94, 399.60, and 398.43 eV, representing pyridinic-N–O, graphitic-N, pyrrolic-N, Fe/Ni-N, and pyridinic-N, thereby confirming the presence of metal-N bonding and N atoms bonded to C in the construction of NCNTs, which is consistent with the FTIR results [29,30]. As the Ni content increases in the xN-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs, the pyridinic-N peak significantly strengthens while the pyrrolic-N peak becomes relatively weaker, confirming theoretical predictions and experimental studies that show initial Ni NPs preferentially grow on the pyridinic-N sites due to their lower binding energy compared to the pyrrolic-N sites [31,32]. To explore the influence of the heterointerface on bonding configurations, high-resolution spectra of Fe 2p (Fig. 2a) and Ni 2p (Fig. 2b) were acquired for various samples. The peaks at around 727.39 eV and 712.67 eV in the high-resolution Fe 2p XPS spectrum indicate Fe3+ ions and suggest that the bound O results from FeO bonds formed during surface oxidation [33]. The Fe 2p 1/2 and Fe 2p 3/2 peaks observed at ∼723.96 and ∼710.26 eV, respectively, indicate the presence of Fe2+ ions in the sulfurized state within 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs [34]. The Fe0 peak at approximately 707.15 eV originates from the inheritance of metallic Fe in the 3 N-FeNi@CNTs precursor [14]. Remarkably, as the nickel ratio increases, the Fe 2p peaks consistently shift to lower binding energies, accompanied by an increase in Fe2+/Fe0 percentage, implying increased electron cloud density and enhanced electro-negativity of the Fe atoms in 1.5 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs compared to those in 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs. For the high-resolution Ni 2p spectrum (Fig. 2b), the redox pair of Ni3+/Ni2+ is represented by the two spin-orbital peaks located at ∼872.82/870.87 eV for Ni 2p 1/2 and ∼855.09/853.40 eV for Ni 2p 3/2, each accompanied by the corresponding satellite peak [10,35–37]. Conspicuously, with a rise in the iron ratio, the Ni 2p peaks progressively shift towards higher binding energies with a decrease in Ni2+ percentage, indicative of heightened electro-positivity exhibited by the Ni atoms within 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs in contrast to those within 1.5 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs [38]. The relative shifts in binding energies of Fe and Ni spectra observed in XPS indicate that the heterojunctions formed at the crystal interfaces of Fe9Ni9S16 and FeS facilitate the transfer of electrons from Fe9Ni9S16 to FeS, resulting in alterations to the electronic structure and consequently modulating the energy storage capability [4,39]. Two spin–orbit peaks (Fig. S7d), S x n – 2p 1/2 at 162.07 eV and S x n – 2p 3/2 at 161.13 eV, can be assigned to the NiS and FeS bonds, validating the successful synthesis of nickel and iron sulfide [4,7]. The presence of CSC bonds at 163.87 eV signifies strong bonding between Fe9Ni9S16/FeS and NCTNs, accompanied by the formation of S-doped CNTs, while the peak observed at 168.48 eV suggests the existence of SO bonds due oxygen adsorption on the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs surface [33,36,40]. The distinctive physical properties of the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure were further investigated utilizing DFT calculations (Fig. 2c,d). The Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure was constructed using the Fe9Ni9S16 (311) and FeS (001) crystal planes, and the calculated density of states (DOS) for FeS demonstrates no state gap at the Fermi level, confirming its metallic nature. However, upon the formation of the heterojunction between FeS and Fe9Ni9S16 in the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS configuration, the bandgap near the Fermi level undergoes significant reshaping, leading to more pronounced energy level separation and an increased density of electronic states. These findings suggest that the metallic characteristics of the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure are enhanced compared to FeS, resulting in improved electrical conductivity. As clearly illustrated in Fig. 2e, based on XPS analysis, it is plausible that prior to contact, the Fermi level of Fe9Ni9S16 exceeds that of FeS. Upon contact between Fe9Ni9S16 and FeS, electrons spontaneously transfer from Fe9Ni9S16 to FeS at the heterojunction interface until their Fermi levels equilibrate, thereby establishing a directional internal electric field. This induces charge redistribution, resulting in negative charge accumulation on the FeS side and positive charge/vacancies accumulation on the Fe9Ni9S16 side, leading to an internal electric field directed from FeS to Fe9Ni9S16. Facilitated by this electric field, the negative charge on the surface of FeS attracts Na+ ions for neutralization, coupling with the local electric field within Fe9Ni9S16 and promoting Na+ diffusion within the heterostructure. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of 3 N-FeNi@CNTs and 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs are depicted in Fig. S8a, b. The surface areas were calculated to be 151.62 and 142.86 m2 g−1, with corresponding BJH desorption mesopore volumes of 0.76 and 0.75 cm3 g−1, respectively. The slight decrease in surface area and pore volume of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs is mainly attributed to the deposition of trace sulfur and the formation of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS nanoparticles during sulfidation. All samples exhibit a noticeable mesoporous structure, with pore diameters predominantly clustered around 3.7 nm, which is advantageous for enhancing electrochemical performance [13]. To confirm the presence of N-doped CNT, Raman spectroscopy was conducted, as shown in Fig. S8c. Evidently, two broad peaks were identified at approximately 1348 and 1571 cm−1, corresponding to the sp 3-hybridized amorphous carbon (D-band) and sp 2-hybridized graphite carbon (G-band) within the carbonaceous framework [41]. The 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs heterostructure, with a higher ID/IG value relative to 3 N-FeNi@CNTs, signifies an increased presence of defects following the sulfuration, resulting in the creation of additional active sites and enhancing energy storage performance. The relative content of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS and N-doped CNT in 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs was estimated through thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under air atmosphere. In TGA tests, both 3 N-FeNi@CNTs and 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs involve combustion of N-doped CNTs oxidation of Fe/Ni and Fe9Ni9S16/FeS, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. S8d, based on the weight loss (11%) and Fe-Ni atomic ratio (3: 1) for 3 N-FeNi@CNTs, the following results can be obtained (N-doped CNTs content: 34.16%; Fe content: 48.76%; Ni content: 17.08%). For 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs, the weight increase between 200 and 450 °C signifies the partial conversion of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS into FeSO4/NiSO4 [41]. The ensuing weight loss reflects the oxidation of FeSO4, Fe9Ni9S16/FeS, and N-doped CNTs [42], leading to the formation of Fe3O4 and NiO, as illustrated in the XRD patterns in the inset of Fig. S8d. Therefore, considering the constant atomic ratio of Fe to Ni before and after sulfidation of the 3 N-FeNi@CNTs precursor and the 36.13% of weight loss after 800 °C, the calculated content of N-doped CNTs, Fe9Ni9S16, and FeS in the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs composite is 27.40%, 35,85%, and 36,75%, respectively. 2.3 Material performance analysis Given the beneficial effects of space-confined Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructures combined with sulfur vacancies, further studies are required to elucidate the Na/Li-ion storage mechanisms and evaluate the electrochemical performance of the prepared 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs. 2.3.1 Na‑ion batteries The Na-ion storage properties of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs in the ether-based electrolyte were assessed utilizing a half-cell setup. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs, within a voltage range of 0.01–3.0 V at 0.1 mV s−1, are presented in Fig. 3 a and compared with N-FeS-3@CNTs (Fig. S9a) and N-Ni3S2-3@CNTs (Fig. S9b) to understand the redox reactions. In the initial cathodic scan, the reduction peak appearing at approximately 1.26 V corresponds to Na+ insertion into Fe9Ni9S16/FeS, forming intermediate phases Na x Fe9Ni9S16 and Na y FeS, while concomitantly, the SEI is formed on the electrode surface [7,43]. The subsequent cathodic peaks at 0.89/0.83 and 0.39 V are linked to the conversion of Na x Fe9Ni9S16/Na y FeS to Na2S, Fe0, and Ni0 [4,7,44,45]. Regarding the initial anodic scan, the reverse conversion reactions account for two oxidation peaks at 1.38 and 1.65 V, whereas the subsequent minor peaks at 1.82 and 2.12 V are indicative of the desodiation of Na x Fe9Ni9S16 and Na y FeS [7,35]. In subsequent scans, due to electrochemical activation and microstructural changes in the active material, the reduction peaks shift from 1.26, 0.89/0.83, and 0.39 V to 1.55, 1.06/0.91, and 0.44/0.34 V, respectively. The oxidation peaks, however, remain nearly unchanged, demonstrating the electrode’s electrochemical reversibility and stable internal structure. Additionally, minor cathodic and anodic peaks appear at 0.02 and 0.08 V, respectively, corresponding to the Na+ insertion and deinsertion in the carbon layer [4,35,45]. The redox peaks observed for 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs in the ether-based electrolyte are similar to those in the ester-based electrolyte (Fig. S9c), suggesting identical electrochemical reaction processes consistent with prior reports [1,4,29,46]. Sodiation/desodiation process equations: (1) Fe9Ni9S16 + xNa+ + xe− ↔ Na x Fe9Ni9S16 (2) FeS + xNa+ + xe− ↔ Na x FeS Conversion process equations: (3) Na x Fe9Ni9S16 + (32 − x)Na+ + (32 − x)e− ↔ 9Fe + 9Ni + 16Na2S (4) Na x FeS + (2 − x)Na+ + (2 − x)e− ↔ Fe + Na2S Fig. 3b illustrates the cycling performance of different samples at 0.1 A g−1. After 150 cycles, the discharge specific capacities of N-FeS-3@CNTs and N-Ni3S2-3@CNTs were 477.4 and 553.0 mAh g−1, respectively, maintaining 89.8% and 92.1% of their initial capacities (average discharge capacity over the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th cycles). Despite FeS in N-FeS-3@CNTs having a higher theoretical capacity than N-Ni3S2-3@CNTs, the volume expansion caused by the alloying sodium storage mechanism reduces cycling stability, resulting in a relatively lower capacity retention. In contrast, the coupling of iron sulfide and nickel sulfide in 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs results in significantly improved capacity and cycling stability, as evidenced by the 114.9% retention after 150 cycles. This suggests that Fe9Ni9S16/FeS composition enhances the Na-ion reaction kinetics through interface regulation and defect induction, thereby improving the capacity and stability. Further evaluation of the cycling stability of samples with increased Ni ratios showed that the 1.5 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs sample had a lower initial discharge capacity but rapidly increased in subsequent cycles, likely due to the reversible growth of a polymer gel film formed from the Na+ degradation in the electrolyte during activation [1]. Conversely, the 1 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs sample, with an even higher Ni ratio, exhibited a high initial cycling capacity that gradually decreased before stabilizing, potentially due to the coupling effect of the excess metal sulfide sites and the relatively aggregated nanotube structure. Clearly, compared to other composites, the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs demonstrates higher reversible capacity and more stable cycling performance with relatively high Coulombic efficiency (CE) during cycling. To gain deeper insights into the trends of capacity decrease, increase, and stabilization throughout cycling, the galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) profiles, along with differential capacity (dQ/dV) plots from selected cycles across the three regions, were examined. As illustrated in Fig. 3c,d, the capacity of the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs electrode decays over the first 20 cycles (Region I), likely due to electrolyte decomposition, unstable SEI formation, and other irreversible side reactions [2,47]. Apart from the initial cycle, the small plateau at 1.56 V in subsequent discharge curves is attributed to Na+ insertion, while the plateaus at 0.9–1.1 V and 0.3–0.4 V are associated with the conversion reactions. During the first 20 cycles, Na+ insertion and reactions within the 0.9–1.1 V range become progressively more pronounced. In the capacity increase period (Region II), more distinct plateaus appear in the GCD profiles. Upon analyzing the dQ/dV curves alongside, the plateaus and peaks in the dQ/dV plots become more distinct, and theplateau associated with conversion reactions around 0.34 V widens over successive cycles. The peaks in the dQ/dV curve shift slightly towards lower voltages, indicating heightened reaction activity. Hence, the capacity increase is due to the progressive activation of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS, greater exposure of active sites, and improved Na+ diffusion kinetics achieved through the formation of a stable SEI film [48]. In the capacity stabilization phase (Region III), the good overlap of the GCD curves in each cycle indicates high reaction reversibility. Combined with the dQ/dV plots, it can be seen that insertion and conversion reactions synergistically contribute to the entire discharge process. Fig. 3e illustrates the rate performance of different electrodes at varying rates every 10 cycles, demonstrating that the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs composite exhibits superior capacity compared to N-FeS-3@CNTs and N-Ni3S2-3@CNTs. Specifically, it delivers discharge capacities of 583.3, 554.8, 540.8, 525.4, 498.2, and 430.9 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 A g−1, respectively, while maintaining high Coulombic efficiency. Remarkably, even when it rapidly returns to 0.5 A g−1, it still provides a capacity of 555.8 mA h g−1. The GCD profiles at various current densities further highlight the excellent rate performance of the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs (Fig. 3f), surpassing most reported metal sulfide anodes for SIBs (Fig. 3g) [7,9,36,49–52]. The long-term cycling stability of different materials was also investigated. As illustrated in Fig. 3i and Fig. S10, although the 1.5 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs sample initially exhibits a higher capacity within a short cycling period compared to the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs composite, its capacity and stability under high current densities were further evaluated. At a current density of 1.0 A g−1, despite experiencing a transient capacity enhancement phase, its capacity gradually declines after reaching a peak. After 400 cycles, both its capacity retention and overall stability are significantly inferior to those of the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs composite. Studies have indicated that, beyond enhancing electrochemical performance through material design, the electrolyte is pivotal in affecting the structural evolution and electrochemical behavior of the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs electrode in SIBs. Fig. 3i illustrates the long-term cycling stability of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs in two different electrolytes. Especially, in the ether-based electrolyte, the electrode retains a discharge capacity of 424.8 mA h g−1 after 1500 cycles at 1.0 A g−1, corresponding to a capacity retention of 78.7% and a low average capacity loss of merely 0.0142% per cycle, indicating excellent cycling longevity and exceeding the performance of other reported sulfide anode materials (Fig. 3h) [7,9,36,49–52]. Conversely, in ester-based electrolyte, it retains only 218.4mA h g−1 after 906 cycles. Moreover, the initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) in the ether-based electrolyte is 74.4%, significantly higher than the 58.4% observed in the ester-based electrolyte. Additionally, it maintains a nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency due to the formation of a stable SEI layer, which prevents further electrolyte consumption and enhances the system’s electrochemical reversibility. While the positive impact of ether-based electrolytes on TEC-based anodes in SIBs is acknowledged [9,53], its precise mechanism remains unclear. SEM, Raman, XRD, XPS, and TEM analysis of cycled electrodes was conducted to demonstrate the effect of ether-based electrolytes on electrode integrity. The SEM image of the pristine 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs electrode (Fig. 4a-1) reveals an intertwined yardlong bean-like structure, suggesting minimal influence from the fabrication process. After 100 cycles, the microstructure remains well-preserved, still exhibiting this yardlong bean-like morphology (Fig. 4b-1). Additionally, the electrode maintains a low swelling ratio of 6.4%, based on changes in thickness (Fig. 4a-2 and b-2), emphasizing its adaptability to volume changes during cycling and robust structural integrity in ether-based electrolytes. Besides, the ex-situ Raman spectra (Fig. 4 c) highlight the defect level changes in NCNT within 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs during sodiation/desodiation. The ID/IG ratio diminishes with increasing sodiation levels, indicative of the Na+ adsorption at the pores, defects, and edge surfaces of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs [43]. During the desodiation process, this ratio progressively recovers to a value approaching its initial state, thereby demonstrating the remarkable reversibility of the anode. The encapsulation of NCNTs is crucial for mitigating structural damage in Na-ion batteries, thereby improving cycle life and stability. Nevertheless, the irreversible damage from cycling limits the potential for complete restoration to the initial state. Fig. 4d illustrates ex-situ XRD patterns of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure representing various sodiation/desodiation states. Distinct diffraction peaks corresponding to Fe9Ni9S16/FeS (JCPDS No. 75–2024 and 75–602) are discernible in the pristine electrode. At 1.16 V during sodiation, the crystalline peaks of FeS2 and Fe9Ni9S16 gradually fade, replaced by signals of Na x FeS, suggesting Na+ insertion into FeS2 and Fe9Ni9S16 lattices and the formation of Na x Fe9Ni9S16 and Na x FeS phases. At deep sodiation (0.01 V), the emergence of diffraction peaks corresponding to Na2S (JCPDS No. 65–2995) signifies the full conversion of Na x Fe9Ni9S16/Na x FeS into Na2S [46,54,55]. Throughout the desodiation phase, the Na2S peaks gradually diminishes, transitioning progressively into Na x Fe9Ni9S16/Na x FeS, and ultimately reverts back to FeS/Fe9Ni9S16 at 3.0 V, demonstrating the reversibility of the electrode. The ex-situ XRD patterns suggest a stepwise reaction within the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure, driven by the distinct reaction potentials and crystal size of FeS and Fe9Ni9S16. Initially, FeS begins conversion at a higher sodiation potential, with Fe9Ni9S16 serving as a template, constraining FeS conversion. During desodiation, the Fe9Ni9S16 formed at a lower potential governs the reformation of FeS at a higher potential. Ex-situ XPS analysis delved deeper into the element’s evolution within 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs under variable states (Fig. 4e,f). Under full sodiation, the Fe 2p spectrum exhibits a pronounced enhancement in the peak associated with Fe0, whereas upon full desodiation, the Fe0 peak almost reverts to its initial state, demonstrating the reversibility of the electrode (Fig. 4e). Metal atoms typically exhibit lower binding energies because the shielding effect of free electrons weakens the effective nuclear charge experienced by outer electrons, leading to a shift in the photoelectron spectrum peaks towards lower binding energies. This explains the shift in the Fe 2p peak towards lower binding energies during full sodiation, due to the increase in the proportion of Fe0, which is a result of the reduction process during sodiation. The Ni 2p spectrum behaves similarly (Fig. 4f), with the Ni2+ peak decreasing or disappearing during sodiation, while the Ni0 peak appears and shifts towards lower binding energies. Conversely, upon full desodiation, the Ni 2p peak shifts back to higher energies, indicating the reformation of nickel-based bonds. Ex-situ HRTEM images and SAED patterns for fully sodiated/desodiated electrodes provide additional confirmation of the phase composition. HRTEM image (Fig. 4g-1) illustrates the graphite-carbon layer confinement of fully sodiated Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure, where distinct lattice fringes (Fig. S11a,b) and diffraction rings (Fig. 4g-2) are assigned to the (220) plane of Na2S and the (110)/(111) planes of Fe0, respectively, with the increased lattice distortion indicating an increase in irreversible defects. Additionally, HRTEM reveals the formation of a uniform SEI layer outside the graphite carbon layer, which ensures stable Na+ migration pathways and contributes to cycling stability. After full desodiation, HRTEM in Fig. 4h-1 confirms the persistence of the heterostructure, with distinct lattices (Fig. S11c,d) and diffraction rings (Fig. 4h-2) indexed to the (100)/(102) planes of FeS and the (311)/(440)/(800) planes of Fe9Ni9S16, respectively, indicating that the intrinsic electric field effect derived from the heterostructure remains active during cycling. Ex-situ analyses confirm the stability of the interface-modulated heterostructure during cycling, which is attributed to its stepwise Na-ion storage and structural evolution, supported by the formation of stable SEI layers. Fig. 4i illustrates the schematic evolution of sodiation and desodiation in the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs electrode. During sodiation, Na+ permeate the graphite carbon layer of NCNTs and gradually infiltrate the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure, inducing phase transformations and causing volume expansion. In contrast, desodiation reverses this process by extracting Na+, returning the electrode to its initial heterostructure and volume. The reversible insertion and extraction of Na+ enable multiple charge–discharge cycles. The superior electrochemical reversibility of electrode is ascribed to rapid reaction kinetics in the ether-based electrolyte and crobust NCNT structure, which evenly distributes nanoscale Fe9Ni9S16/FeS particles within a conductive graphite carbon matrix. The Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure furnishes plentiful active nanodomains for fast conversion reactions, while the NCNTs act as physical barriers, accommodating electrode volume expansion, and enhancing the electronic conductivity through N-doped sites and sulfur vacancies. The redistribution of charge at the heterointerfaces generates an internal electric field, which further reduces the diffusion barrier and improves Na-ion transport efficiency. The synergistic effects of the carbon encapsulation layer, heterostructure, sulfur vacancies, and N-doped sites deliver superior Na-ion storage performance for the electrode. To comprehensively investigate the differences in Na-ion kinetics of as-prepared electrodes in ether/ester-based electrolytes, a series of analyses including CV, galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were conducted. The CV curves at diverse scanning rates, obtained through the isothermal heating map, are presented in Fig. 5 a,c, with specific changes in Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs in both electrolyte types depicted in Fig. S12a,d. Distinct redox peaks (OP1-4 and RP1-4) can be observed, corresponding to multi-element redox reactions involving Fe2+/Fe3+ and Ni2+/Ni3+. The width of the dark red line in the CV curve reflects the electrochemical activity of the electrode material during redox reactions, where a narrower peak width generally indicates higher material activity [56]. It is noteworthy that, the dark red line width of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs in the ether-based electrolyte is smaller than that in the ester-based electrolyte at 1.0 mV s−1, suggesting enhanced electrochemical activity in the ether-based electrolyte. As the scan rate increases from 0.2 to 1.0 mV s−1, noticeable leftward shifts in the cathodic peak and rightward shifts in the anodic peak are observed, indicating a subtle electrochemical polarization [35]. Due to peak overlapping and interfacial polarization, some peaks are not clearly discernible in the ester-based electrolyte. The peak current ( i ) increases with the increment of scan rate ( v ), illustrating the pseudocapacitive behavior of the electrochemical process, described by the following equation [51]. (5) i = i cap + i diff (6) i = a v b (7) l og 10 i = b l og 10 v + l og 10 a Typically, the storage mechanisms governed by diffusion control and pseudocapacitance processes are associated with b values of 0.5 and 1, respectively [49]. The calculated b values for 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs electrode in ether-based electrolyte (Fig. S12b,e) exceed those in ester-based electrolyte, suggesting enhanced interfacial kinetics and a greater capacitive contribution to charge storage coupled with ether-based electrolyte. For further clarification, the capacitive contribution at different scan rates can be validated utilizing the following equation [39]. (8) i = k 1 v + k 2 v 0.5 (9) i v 0.5 = k 1 v 0.5 + k 2 In the equations, k 1 and k 2 represent the extent of capacitive behavior and the diffusion-controlled process, respectively. Fig. 5b, d illustrate that as the scan rate increases from 0.2 to 1 mV s−1, the capacitive contribution in the ether-based electrolyte rises from 72.5% to 81.6%, significantly exceeding that in the ester-based electrolyte. This increase is largely due to the ether-based electrolyte’s lower viscosity and higher ionic conductivity, which promote faster ion migration and surface electrochemical reactions, thereby enhancing pseudocapacitive performance. After data collection and fitting, the results at 1.0 mV s−1 are illustrated by the shaded regions in Fig. S12c, f. High capacitive contributions enable favorable electrochemical kinetics at high current densities, thereby promoting cycling stability and rate performance. For comparison, the kinetic behavior of N-FeS-3@CNTs and N-Ni3S2-3@CNTs electrodes in ether-based electrolytes was analyzed. It was observed that the deep red peak width for N-FeS-3@CNTs was significantly larger than that of N-Ni3S2-3@CNTs, corresponding to a significantly lower pseudocapacitive contribution of N-FeS-3@CNTs compared to N-Ni3S2-3@CNTs (Fig. S13), indicating that the presence of Ni elements is advantageous for enhancing the pseudocapacitive contribution. Especially noteworthy is that as the Fe to Ni ratio transitions from 3:1 to 1:1 (Fig. S14), the redox peaks progressively sharpen, indicative of enhanced electrochemical activity. However, the pseudocapacitive contribution initially experiences a slight enhancement before significantly diminishing. This behavior highlights the synergistic effect between the active material and its structural configuration in promoting Na-ion kinetics. The heterostructures and sulfur vacancies within Fe9Ni9S16 and FeS facilitate both high reaction kinetics and effective utilization of active materials, ensuring excellent Na-ion storage performance. The Na+ diffusion coefficients ( D Na + ) of xN-Fe9Ni9 S16/FeS-3@CNTs can be calculated through analysis of GITT data, applying the following equation [47]. (10) D Na + = 4 π τ m b V m M b S 2 Δ E s Δ E τ 2 τ ≪ L 2 D Na + where τ represents the relaxation time; m b , V m , and M b are the mass loading, molar volume, and molecular weight of active material; S stands for the interfacial area between electrolyte and electrode; Δ E s and Δ E τ refer the steady-state voltage variation after each current pulse and voltage variation during the constant current pulse, respectively [35]. Fig. 5e, f and Fig. S15a, b present the GITT curves alongside the calculated diffusion coefficients of different electrodes in both ether-based and ester-based electrolytes. The average Log10( D Na + ) for xN-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs (Fig. 5e and Fig. S15a,b) in the ether-based electrolyte decreases with increasing Fe9Ni9S16 proportion, (−11.237 > −11.363 > −11.978), possibly due to the constrained porosity and disordered structure of the 1 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs composite (shown in SEM images). Moreover, the higher average Log10( D Na + ) (Fig. 5e, f) exhibited by 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs in ether-based electrolyte (−11.237) compared to those in ester-based electrolyte (−11.882) is associated with the higher solubility of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS active material, better ion conductivity, and the higher polarity of ether-based electrolyte. The inset in Fig. 5e illustrates the volume evolution during cycling, highlighting the structural stability of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs, which supports its enhanced diffusion and electrochemical performance in the ether-based electrolyte. The EIS profiles (inset: corresponding equivalent circuit diagram) depicting the comparison of the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs electrode after the 1st, 20th, and 50th cycles, operated at 0.5 A g−1 in ether/ester-based electrolytes, are presented in Fig. 5g,i. The observed semicircle and linear in the high-frequency and low-frequency regions, respectively, are indicative of the resistance (R; electrolyte, SEI layer and charge transfer) and Warburg impedance (Zw ) [9,49,50]. The smaller semicircle in the ether-based electrolyte, with only a slight increase during cycling, indicates a faster charge transfer rate and a more stable SEI interface compared to the ester-based electrolyte [38]. Based on formulas ( Z re = R + σ ω 2 π f - 0.5 ; D Na + = R 2 T 2 2 S 2 n 4 F 4 C Na + 2 σ ω 2 ) [1] and linear fitting calculations (Fig. 5h,j), it is demonstrated that the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs electrode in the ether electrolyte exhibits higher Na-ion reaction kinetics across different cycles. To further evaluate the surface activity and thermodynamic advantages of the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterointerface, four models were constructed to calculate the Na+ adsorption energies ( Δ E a d s ). The optimized Δ E a d s for FeS and Fe9Ni9S16, along with their respective adsorption structures, are presented in Fig. 5k, Table. S2, and the inset of Fig. 5. For the FeS-1 adsorption site, it is located at a “vacant” or “on-top” position on the surface, meaning the Na atom is directly above an underlying atom. This configuration enables the Na atom to form strong chemical bonds with surface atoms, particularly with metal atoms such as Fe or Na, and S atoms. As a result, this site exhibits high stability with a significant Δ E a d s (−1.11 eV). In contrast, In contrast, the FeS-2 site is on a relatively flat region of the surface, possibly at a bridge or hollow site, where the sodium atom is positioned between two surface atoms or slightly below the surface. Due to weaker interactions, the Na atom is closer to the surface, leading to a lower Δ E a d s (−0.82 eV) and reduced stability. Structural optimization reveals that the Na atom tends to occupy the FeS-1 position, coordinating with four neighboring S atoms to form NaS bonds. As expected, the Δ E a d s at both sites 1 (−2.12 eV) and 2 (−3.27 eV) on the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure are significantly higher than those on the FeS model, indicating that the heterostructure enhances Na+ adsorption and provides more active sites. The Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-2 heterostructure exhibits a more complex surface structure, potentially offering additional adsorption sites or a more stable environment. While the Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-1 structure is relatively flat, the atomic arrangement of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-2 displays more pronounced three-dimensional features, which may result in stronger Coulombic attraction for Na+ adsorption. 2.3.2 Li-ion batteries To unravel the kinetic optimization mechanism of heterostructures, an extensive investigation into the Li-ion storage processes of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs was conducted. In Fig. 6 a, the CV curves for different cycles at 1 mV s−1 are presented. During the initial cathodic process, the reduction peaks at 0.76 and 1.26 V likely correspond to the transformation of Fe9Ni9S16/FeS into metallic Fe, Ni, and Li2S, along with SEI film formation [57]. Due to the irreversible nature of the SEI film, this pronounced reduction peak disappears in subsequent cycles. In the initial anodic process, prominent oxidation peaks at 1.94 V and 2.47 V suggest the conversion of metallic Ni, Fe, and Li2S into Fe9Ni9S16/FeS [1]. The peaks remain almost unchanged in subsequent cycles, indicating excellent cyclic stability. The peak currents decrease in successive cycles due to polysulfide interaction with the electrolyte [1]. Minor peak shifts suggest reduced electrode polarization, potentially enhancing cycling performance. Lithiation/delithiation process equations: (11) Fe9Ni9S16 + xLi+ + xe− ↔ Li x Fe9Ni9S16 (12) FeS + xLi+ + xe− ↔ Li x FeS Conversion process equations: (13) Li x Fe9Ni9S16 + (32 − x)Li+ + (32 − x)e− ↔ 9Fe + 9Ni + 16Li2S (14) Li x FeS + (2 − x)Li+ + (2 − x)e− ↔ Fe + Li2S The electrode demonstrates a satisfying cycling capacity of approximately 774.4 mAh g−1 after 210 cycles at 0.5 A g−1, outperforming most reported metal sulfides (Fig. S16), maintaining capacity retention of 102.6%, as illustrated in Fig. 6b. The increase in capacity over cycles is attributed to the reversible expansion of the polymeric gel film formed by electrolyte degradation [1]. Fig. 6c demonstrates the remarkable rate capability of the electrode from 0.1 to 5 A g−1. In the step curve, the capacity of the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs gradually decreases and stabilizes at different current densities, with discharge capacities of 940.9, 910.9, 796.9, 606.4, 464.9, and 350.0 mA h g−1, respectively. When it returns back to 0.1 A g−1, the capacity rapidly recovers to 923.8 mAh g−1, indicating a robust structure and effective active sites. The matched GCD curves at various current densities display similar charge–discharge plateaus (Fig. 6d), further indicating relatively superior rate capability and low polarization. Measure the CV curves at different scan rates (Fig. S17a) to further elucidate the Li-ion storage kinetics of 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs. As the scan rate increases, the oxidation/reduction peaks shift in opposite directions, suggesting slight polarization of electrode. The calculated b-values of the redox peaks are 0.67 and 0.63 (Fig. S17b), indicating that the electrochemical Li+ insertion/extraction behavior exhibits both diffusion-control and pseudocapacitance mechanism. Fig. S17c illustrates that the capacitance contribution rate at 1.0 mV s−1 is 86.0%. With the scan rate increasing from 0.2 to 1.0 mV s−1, the capacitance contribution rises from 73.2% to 86.0% (Fig. 6f), with higher pseudocapacitance contribution favoring rapid Li-ion storage kinetics and excellent rate performance [58]. The intertwined yardlong bean-like network structure establishes rapid transport channels between nanotubes, facilitating efficient electron/ion conduction while forming a strain-buffering region. Rich heterointerfaces between Fe9Ni9S16 and FeS with distinct Fermi levels, coupled with sulfur vacancies and N-doped sites, synergistically enhance structural stability, improve electrical conductivity, and increase the number of active sites. 3 Conclusions In summary, the precise regulation of sulfur vacancy-containing Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructures within NCNTs was achieved for the first time through a combination of Fe/Ni-catalyzed dicyandiamide thermal decomposition and subsequent sulfurization. The combination of NCNTs-encapsulated nanostructures and a multi-component architecture offers numerous advantages to the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs composite: enhanced electron migration and conductivity via carbon encapsulation, reduced volume expansion during cycling, improved charge transfer kinetics from Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructures, and increased Na+/Li+ diffusion rates due to doping and vacancies. Strengthened by the above synergistic factors, the composite demonstrates impressive electrochemical performance, achieving a substantial reversible capacity of up to 682.1 mA h g−1 for SIBs at 0.1 A g−1 and 782.7 mA h g−1 for LIBs at 0.5 A g−1. In addition, it exhibits remarkable cycling durability and outstanding rate performance in SIBs, retaining 78.7% of its capacity after 1500 cycles at 1 A g−1 with an ether-based electrolyte. Electrochemical analyses, ex-situ characterization, and DFT calculations were used to investigate storage mechanisms and phase transitions, revealing the relationship between structure, composition, and performance. This work offers a novel perspective on the construction of heterogeneous interfaces, structural optimization, and their applications in next-generation rechargeable batteries. coredata.dc:description: Tailoring 1D nanotubes with refined interfacial interactions and optimized adsorption sites presents a highly promising yet challenging strategy for advancing Na/Li-ion batteries (SIBs/LIBs). Herein, the intertwined yardlong bean-like Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructures with sulfur vacancies encapsulated in N-doped carbon nanotubes (3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs) are controllably synthesized through Fe/Ni-catalyzed pyrolysis of dicyandiamide followed by sulfidation strategies. 1D nanotubes with robust outer walls and internal cavity structures shorten the diffusion paths of ions/electrons and buffer volume expansion and aggregation of active materials. The Fe9Ni9S16/FeS heterostructure provides a powerful driving force for charge transfer by forming built-in electric fields, optimizing ion adsorption, while the Fe9Ni9S16 features a wider interlayer spacing that allows for frequent Na+/Li+ insertion and extraction, thereby enhancing the reaction kinetics within the electrode. Driven by these synergistic factors, the 3 N-Fe9Ni9S16/FeS-3@CNTs demonstrates remarkable electrochemical performance, achieving a substantial reversible capacity of up to 682.1mA h g−1 for SIBs at 0.1 A g−1 and 782.7 mA h g−1 for LIBs at 0.5 A g−1, alongside exceptional cycling stability in SIBs, maintaining 78.7% of its capacity after 1500 cycles at 1 A g−1 coupling with the ether-based electrolyte. Employing various electrochemical analyses in conjunction with ex-situ characterization techniques and Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations, the storage mechanisms and phase transition processes are investigated, elucidating the structure-composition-performance relationships. This work paves the way for a new strategy in designing advanced materials with engineered heterostructures and controllable defects for energy conversion and storage devices.
